page.title: 03BIRD WATCHING,LYDART
page.content: Extensive mixed woodland,steep slopes,rough grazing,arable farmland and gardens make Lydart a good place for bird watching. Buzzards breed in the woods and are heard calling as they soar above the woods in late autumn and early spring to mark their territory. Curlews and little owls also breed locally. Migrant visitors include the grass- hopper warbler,which sings for one or two days in April - perhaps they also breed here. Winter migrants include large flocks of redwings which roost in the woods and are seen in gardens eating berries. The most exciting sound of spring and summer evenings is the roading of the woodcock as it circles overhead before descending into the woods for the night.
